prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To detect weak lines of dust-related molecules, we perform spectral averaging into 50 km/s. The source velocity width traced in dense gas (high-J CO, HCN, HCO+, and CS) is ~ 400 km/s (Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012; Scoville et al. 2015).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Before deriving the SiO(2-1) and HNCO(4-3) flux, We estimate the CH3OH(2-1) peak flux by using the observed CO(3-2) peak flux (2.1 Jy/beam with 2.0" * 1.8"; Iono et al. 2007) and assuming a CO(3-2)/CH3OH(2-1) ratio from the literatures (~ 250; Meier & Turner 2005, Sakamoto et al. 2014, Saito et al. 2015, Michiyama et al. in prep.). According to the fowwloing calculation, 2.1/1000 / 250 * (0.4*0.4/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 4.6 we derive the expected CH3OH(2-1) peak/beam = 4.6 mJy. Assuming the HNCO(4-3)/CH3OH(2-1) ~ 1 (Meier & Turner 2005) and the SiO(2-1)/CH3OH(2-1) ~ 0.25 (Garcia-Burillo et al. 2010), we derive the expected HNCO(4-3) = 4.6 mJy/beam and SiO(2-1) peak = 1.2 mJy/beam. In order to detect the SiO peak, we need at least the sensitivity of 0.4 mJy.
For the comntinuum, the expected 115 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (85.0/345.8)^2 * (0.4*0.4/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 0.14 mJy/beam).

To detect weak lines of dust-related molecules, we perform spectral averaging into 50 km/s. The source velocity width traced in dense gas (high-J CO, HCN, HCO+, and CS) is ~ 400 km/s (Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012; Scoville et al. 2015).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

We estimate the CH3OH(2-1) peak flux by using the observed CO(3-2) peak flux (2.1 Jy/beam with 2.0" * 1.8"; Iono et al. 2007) and assuming a CO(3-2)/CH3OH(2-1) ratio from the literatures (~ 250; Meier & Turner 2005, Sakamoto et al. 2014, Saito et al. 2015, Michiyama et al. in prep.). According to the fowwloing calculation, 2.1/1000 / 250 * (0.4*0.4/(2.0*1.8)) ~ 4.6 we derive the expected CH3OH(2-1) peak/beam = 4.6 mJy. Assuming the HNCO(4-3)/CH3OH(2-1) = CS(2-1)/CH3OH(2-1) ~ 1 (Meier & Turner 2005) and the HNCO(5-4)/HNCO(4-3) ~ 1, we derive the expected HNCO(5-4) and CS(2-1) peak = 4.6 mJy/beam.
For the comntinuum, the expected 115 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (98.0/345.8)^2 * (0.4*0.4/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 0.19 mJy/beam).

To detect weak lines of dust-related molecules, we perform spectral averaging into 50 km/s. The source velocity width traced in dense gas (high-J CO, HCN, HCO+, and CS) is ~ 400 km/s (Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012; Scoville et al. 2015).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Assuming SiO(3-2)/SiO(2-1) ~ 1 (the nearest LIRG NGC 1068; Garcia-Burillo et al. 2010), SiO(3-2) peak = 1.2 mJy/beam (SiO(2-1) peak = 1.2 mJy/beam).
For the comntinuum, the expected 115 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (140.0/345.8)^2 * (0.4*0.4/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 0.36 mJy/beam).

To detect weak lines of dust-related molecules, we perform spectral averaging into 50 km/s. The source velocity width traced in dense gas (high-J CO, HCN, HCO+, and CS) is ~ 400 km/s (Iono et al. 2007; Feruglio et al. 2012; Scoville et al. 2015).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Assuming CH3OH(3-2)/CH3OH(2-1) ~ 1 (Martin et al. 2006), CH3OH(5-4) peak = 4.6 mJy/beam (SiO(2-1) peak = 4.6 mJy/beam). For robust determination of excitatino parameters using the rotation diagram, we need at least ~ 7 sigma for higher trnasitions of CH3OH, SiO, and HNCO.
For the comntinuum, the expected 115 GHz flux is estimated by using the 345GHz peak flux (42 mJy/beam with 1.8" * 1.6" beam; Iono et al. 2007) and the Rayleigh-Jeans approximation (42 * (135.0/345.8)^2 * (0.4*0.4/(1.8*1.6)) ~ 0.36 mJy/beam).
To detect weak lines of dust-related molecules, we perform spectral averaging into 50 km/s.

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Since there are no studies of CO line imaging, we assume the molecular gas properties of IRASF16399-0937 are similar to that of NGC6240, so that the expected line peaks are also same as the previous TJ. This is reliable assumption because thier IR luminosity and their IRAC source size are similar (log(L(IR)/Lsun) ~ 11.93 and 11.63 for NGC 6240 and IRASF16399-0937, respectively; Armus et al. 2009 and Sales et al. 2015).

This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Since there are no studies of CO line imaging, we assume the molecular gas properties of IRASF16399-0937 are similar to that of NGC6240, so that the expected line peaks are also same as the previous TJ. This is reliable assumption because thier IR luminosity and their IRAC source size are similar (log(L(IR)/Lsun) ~ 11.93 and 11.63 for NGC 6240 and IRASF16399-0937, respectively; Armus et al. 2009 and Sales et al. 2015).

This is reliable assumption because thier IR luminosity and their IRAC source size are similar (log(L(IR)/Lsun) ~ 11.93 and 11.63 for NGC 6240 and IRASF16399-0937, respectively; Armus et al. 2009 and Sales et al. 2015).

For NGC 6240 (luminosity distance = 103 Mpc), the requested angular resolution (0.4") is consistent with ~ 200 pc. This is enough to resolve large giant molecular associations (GMAs) in nearby LIRGs which typically have 200 pc diameters (e.g., high-resolution studies provided by Konig et al. 2013; Xu et al. 2015).
The largest angular scale is provided by SMA observations of CO(3-2) emission (Iono et al. 2007).

Since there are no studies of CO line imaging, we assume the molecular gas properties of IRASF16399-0937 are similar to that of NGC6240, so that the expected line peaks are also same as the previous TJ. This is reliable assumption because thier IR luminosity and their IRAC source size are similar (log(L(IR)/Lsun) ~ 11.93 and 11.63 for NGC 6240 and IRASF16399-0937, respectively; Armus et al. 2009 and Sales et al. 2015).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Galaxy merger produces large-scale shocks due to the collision between the progenitors gas disks. Since shocks affect icy mantles and/or dust grain cores (e.g., Si), dust-related molecules should be enhanced in the gas phase. Our 3 mm observations with the cycle 0 and 2 ALMA detected one of the shock tracers, CH3OH (2-1), in nearby merging galaxies, NGC 3110 and VV 114. To develop the results, we require multi-transition observations of well-known shock tracers, CH3OH, HNCO, and SiO emission, for the two molecular hydrogen emitting galaxies (MOHEGs), NGC 6240 and IRAS F16399-0937, in order to constrain gas excitation and abundances of dust-related molecules quantitatively in merging galaxies. The targets are selected from the Spitzer/IRS observations of nearby luminous infrared galaxies which show the strong H2 (1-0) S(1) emission. Multi wavelength studies revealed that AGN nuclei in both targets show less contribution to the total IR and emission lines. Therefore, the strong H2 (with strong H and suppressed PAH) may be due to galaxy collisions or radio jet feedback from the nuclei, so that NGC 6240 and IRAS F16399-0937 are ideal for studying merger-induced shocks.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
